The invention can be applied to the fabrication of both n-channel and p-channel MOS field effect semiconductor devices. The LDD structure can be formed by siliciding the gate electrode and/or the source/drain region, which reduces the sheet resistance of the source/drain region and prevents the transconductance from being lowered due to hot-carrier injection.

</summary>

<summary>
The invention relates to an improved end-user interface for Internet-protocol (IP) telephone communication. It provides an enhanced radio telephone that can be connected to a PC and used as a significantly improved IP telephone. The enhanced radio telephone includes an internal speech coder which is implemented for low power consumption, allowing it to be used with a relatively low-performance PC for effective IP telephony. The invention reduces speech delay, provides a low-cost IP telephone solution, and reduces echo problems associated with conventional IP telephones. The enhanced radio telephone can operate in either wireless-telephone mode or IP-telephone mode, and switching between the two modes can be initiated manually or automatically. The invention provides an improved IP telephone that is more convenient, economical, and efficient than conventional IP telephones.</summary>

<summary>
The invention relates to devices for producing electrical power from surface waves on a water body, specifically wave energy converters that capture energy from subsurface differences in hydrostatic pressure and/or enhanced surge or pitch. The device consists of one or more gas tight containers submerged to a depth slightly below anticipated wave and swell troughs, with a fixed depth rigid end and a movable rigid end connected by a flexible, gas tight, reinforced bellows. The containers are designed to capture both hydrostatic (heave) and hydrokinetic wave energy (surge or pitch), and can be adjusted for tidal depth variations and severe sea-states. The device can be oriented vertically, horizontally, or in any other orientation, and can be connected to a floating overhead device to increase stroke and energy capture. The invention overcomes the limitations of prior art devices, including high cost, low energy capture efficiency, and restricted stroke and energy capture due to partial vacuum or internal gas pressure.</summary>

<summary>

The invention pertains to the field of scraped surface heat exchangers, specifically the mounting of blades onto the central drive shaft. Scraped surface heat exchangers are widely used in industry, particularly in food processing, and include a cylindrical outer tube with a central drive shaft and radially extending paddles or blades. The blades are hingedly connected to the drive shaft and are typically mounted using pins, which can be cumbersome to install. The invention provides a method and apparatus to facilitate the mounting of blades onto the drive shaft while still using a pin type connection. The apparatus includes a blade with L-shaped locking tracks on both sides, which interfere with the pins to prevent the blade from sliding off. The locking tracks allow the blade to be installed at an angle and then slid downwardly along the pins until it reaches the correct position. The blade can only be installed with the correct side facing up, ensuring that the scraper edge is correctly oriented against the inside of the outer tube. The provision of locking tracks on both sides of the blade allows for acceptable performance while reducing the amount of thinned track blade area. The invention provides a significant benefit in that the blades will stay oriented and will not fall off the pins, even if they are left free to pivot about any angle.

</summary>

<summary>
The invention is a process and apparatus for detecting and eliminating defective and/or incorrectly positioned cigarettes in a cigarette magazine of a cigarette-production and/or cigarette-packaging machine. The process involves using an optical checking element, such as a camera, to scan an image of the cigarette magazine and evaluate it using an image-processing device. If the image deviates from a reference image or value, an error signal is produced. The error signal triggers an ejecting unit to eject a plurality of cigarettes located in an ejecting zone assigned to the ejecting unit. The ejecting unit has a front wall and a rear wall that are displaced in the direction of the chute when actuated, allowing the cigarettes to be ejected. The cigarette magazine has four shaft groups and four ejecting units, each assigned to an evaluation zone and an ejecting zone. The camera scans an image of all four evaluation zones, and the image is subdivided into four evaluation zones during image processing. The ejecting unit is actuated with a time delay after a defective or incorrectly positioned cigarette is detected, allowing the cigarette to move downwards into the ejecting zone before being ejected.</summary>

<summary>
The present invention relates to a device for interconnecting high voltage cables with apparatus and/or other high voltage cables, providing a simplified connection system with a common cable connection system for all accessories and interconnections. The invention features a cable termination and a rigid insulator with a conical interface surface, allowing for a compact design, lower material and installation cost, and complete independence between gas insulated switchgear and cable installations. The invention has various applications, including SF6 terminals, transformer terminals, out-door terminals, straight through joints, transition joints, and joints between two apparatus. 
</summary>

<summary>
The invention presents a fixing mechanism for a tool, which can be applied in various technologies, including machining, cutting, punching, and forming work. The mechanism comprises a tool, a tool frame, and a tool holder, with at least one connecting surface shaped as a curved surface, allowing for a simple and secure fixing of the tool in the tool holder.</summary>

<summary>

The invention relates to switching circuitry for driving display drivers, particularly for providing high-speed switching while minimizing electromagnetic interference (EMI) output. Conventional techniques, such as charge pump circuits and switching regulators, have limitations in terms of current driving capability and EMI generation. The invention proposes a modified switching regulator circuit that creates multiple circuit paths to cancel out radiated noise and uses terminal leads to sink EMI. The circuit is designed to produce high efficiency and low EMI output, making it suitable for driving large digital displays such as those used in Apple iPhone and iPod Touch products. The invention also includes embodiments that use indium tin oxide (ITO) as a bonding wire material and provide additional paths to further reduce EMI effects.

</summary>

<summary>
A vehicle battery rebalancing system is described to correct cell voltage imbalance conditions. The system includes a controller that causes the cells to acquire charge for a period of time such that at the expiration of the period of time, the voltages of the cells are approximately equal. The rate at which charge is acquired by the cells may be different among at least some of the cells for at least a determined portion of the period of time. The system may spend up to 50% of the total time taken to rebalance and charge a battery on rebalancing. A battery cell's maximum capacity can be found using the relationship ΔIhr = ΔSOC * Ihr max. The energy content of a battery cell can be approximated from the equation ε = ∫ρ·dt, where ρ is the power applied to the cell over time. The system determines the desired voltage for each cell to provide a specified energy content, taking into account the cell's maximum capacity and the required energy. The system also determines the time required to charge the battery pack, which is dependent on the cell requiring the greatest ΔIhrs, the cell requiring the least ΔIhrs, and the method of balancing the cells to the same voltage. The system can balance and charge the cells using a resistive circuitry activation time, or by activating the resistive circuitry and enabling the battery charger for each cell.
</summary>

<summary>
The invention is an AC-to-DC converter that converts an AC input voltage to a constant DC voltage, eliminating low frequency and high frequency flicker, and reducing eye fatigue to a minimum level. The converter includes various components such as input protection circuit, EMI filter, rectifier, filter, converter, output filter, and control circuit, which can be implemented in different ways. The invention can be used in various applications such as bus AC to DC converter, PFC converter, computer power supply, TV power supply, and more.
</summary>

<summary>
The invention is a system for controlling daylight and artificial illumination in a space, including a sensor for sensing an illumination level, a plurality of dimmable electric lamps, and a control system controlling the dimming levels of the lamps to achieve a desired illumination profile. The system can also control window treatments to minimize or eliminate sun glare. The control system can be based on a closed loop algorithm using interior light sensors, and can adjust the dimming levels of the lamps and the position of the window treatments to achieve the desired illumination profile. The system can also be controlled manually, and can account for manual overrides of the window treatments.
</summary>

<summary>The Transportation Security Administration (TSA) has made significant progress in improving aviation security since the events of September 11, 2001, but still faces challenges in areas such as air cargo security, general aviation security, and airport perimeter security. To address these challenges, TSA has implemented various initiatives, including the use of technology and information to control access to secure areas, the development of a comprehensive plan for air cargo security, and the adoption of a risk management approach to guide federal programs and responses.</summary>

<summary>The Lobbying Disclosure Act (LDA) and the Internal Revenue Code (IRC) have different definitions of lobbying, which can lead to inconsistent registration and reporting requirements. The LDA definition covers lobbying at the federal level, while the IRC definitions cover lobbying at the federal, state, and local levels, and also include grassroots lobbying, which is not covered by the LDA definition.</summary>

<summary>
The Government Accountability Office (GAO) has been assessing strategic sourcing in federal acquisitions for over a decade, highlighting its potential to drive efficiencies and yield benefits beyond savings. Despite the benefits, federal agencies have made little progress in incorporating strategic sourcing leading practices, with only a small fraction of procurement spending managed through strategic sourcing efforts. In contrast, private sector companies have successfully implemented strategic sourcing to achieve significant savings, particularly in services procurement, by analyzing spending patterns, centralizing procurement decisions, and developing category-specific procurement strategies. To improve strategic sourcing in the federal government, the GAO recommends that agencies adopt leading practices, increase spending through strategic sourcing, and direct efforts at high spend categories, such as services.</summary>

<summary>
The current surface transportation programs in the United States are ineffective in addressing the nation's transportation challenges, such as increasing congestion and growing freight demand. The programs lack a well-defined vision of the national interest and federal role, and many funds are distributed through formulas that do not relate to needs or performance. The Highway Trust Fund is facing a fiscal sustainability crisis due to increased spending without commensurate increases in revenues. To address these issues, the Government Accountability Office (GAO) recommends restructuring the federal approach to surface transportation, creating well-defined goals, establishing a clear federal role, incorporating performance and accountability, employing the best tools and approaches, and ensuring fiscal sustainability. Various funding and financing options, such as taxes, user fees, bonding, loans, and public-private partnerships, can be used to fund investments in the nation's infrastructure. The GAO also recommends that Congress reexamine the federal role in transportation and develop objective criteria for identifying national public interests in highway public-private partnerships.</summary>

<summary>
The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) engages in three primary activities: aviation safety oversight, air traffic control (ATC), and airport infrastructure development. The costs associated with these activities depend on the nature and usage of the specific service provided, and the FAA's funding structure has been criticized for not accurately reflecting the costs imposed by users. Alternative funding options, such as a fuel tax, weight/distance charges, and certification charges, have been proposed to address revenue adequacy, equity, and efficiency concerns. The use of debt financing for capital projects has also been considered, but raises concerns about encumbering future resources and the potential for increased borrowing costs.

</summary>

<summary>The Department of Defense (DOD) has been working to identify individuals who were potentially exposed to chemical or biological substances during previously classified tests, but its efforts have been hindered by a lack of clear objectives, inconsistent oversight, and inadequate coordination with other entities. DOD has identified over 20,700 servicemembers who may have been exposed, but has not taken adequate steps to notify civilians who may have been exposed, and has not conducted a thorough cost-benefit analysis to determine the feasibility of continuing its search for additional individuals.</summary>

<summary>The Mexican government has been working to combat the growing power of criminal groups, known as DTOs, which have been trafficking firearms from the United States into Mexico. U.S. agencies, including ATF and ICE, have been working together with Mexican authorities to stem the flow of illicit firearms, but challenges persist due to corruption, turnover in Mexican law enforcement, and inadequate monitoring of interagency collaboration.</summary>

<summary>
The National Criminal History Improvement Program (NCHIP) is a federal grant program managed by the Bureau of Justice Statistics (BJS) to improve the accuracy, completeness, and accessibility of criminal history records. NCHIP has provided over $438 million in grants to states, the District of Columbia, and U.S. territories since 1995. The program aims to build a national infrastructure to facilitate the interstate exchange of criminal history and other relevant records. States have made progress in automating their records and making them accessible nationally, with the percentage of automated records increasing from 79% in 1993 to 89% in 2001. However, challenges remain, including the availability of and access to arrest disposition information, which is necessary for timely presale background checks of persons purchasing firearms. The FBI's National Instant Criminal Background Check System (NICS) relies on accurate and complete records to conduct background checks. States have used NCHIP funds to improve their records and systems, with the majority of funds going towards NICS/III/criminal records improvements and disposition reporting improvements. The 5 case-study states (California, Maryland, Mississippi, Texas, and West Virginia) have used NCHIP funds to improve their records and systems, with California allocating the majority of its funds towards NICS/III/criminal records improvements. The priority states (Maine, Mississippi, New Mexico, Vermont, and West Virginia) have also made progress in automating their records, with 3 of the 5 states participating in the III system.

<summary>The Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act (CERCLA) created the Superfund program to clean up the nation's most severely contaminated hazardous waste sites. The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) uses incineration as a cleanup remedy, which involves burning substances in a controlled flame to convert contamination into residual products. The EPA has established various safeguards to ensure the safe operation of incinerators, including setting site-specific standards, monitoring emissions, and providing 24-hour on-site oversight, but has not fully implemented some of its own policies and guidelines.</summary>

<summary>
The Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) received an unqualified opinion on its financial statements for fiscal years 2007 and 2006, but identified significant internal control weaknesses that may affect financial reporting and compliance with laws and regulations. The audit found a material weakness in the financial reporting process, including errors in calculating accounts receivable and preparing financial statement disclosures, as well as significant deficiencies in information security, property and equipment controls, and accounting for budgetary resources. The SEC has made progress in addressing some of these weaknesses, but still needs to implement effective controls to prevent or detect material misstatements in financial statements. The audit also noted that the SEC's financial management system does not conform to the systems requirements of OMB Circular No. A-127, Financial Management Systems, and that the agency's internal control over financial reporting is not effective.</summary>

<summary>The U.S. Postal Service had a workforce of about 765,000 employees at the end of fiscal year 1997, with women and minorities underrepresented in certain positions. A study by Aguirre International found that women and minorities were less represented in higher EAS positions than in lower EAS positions, and the Service's diversity program was not effectively capturing and using data to identify barriers to promotion. The Postal Service has implemented 23 initiatives to address the recommendations in the Aguirre report, but still lacks reliable data on the flow of applicants through its promotion processes.</summary>

<summary>
The Department of Defense (DOD) defines a Military Working Dog (MWD) as a canine bred or acquired to support operations in the protection of installations, resources, and personnel. According to "Robby's Law," enacted in 2000, the military is required to make MWDs available for adoption at the end of their "useful life" or when no longer needed. The DOD uses three systems to track information about MWDs, including their removal from service, and the number of adopted, transferred, or euthanized MWDs has varied over the past 5 years. Adopted MWDs may require preventative care and may have medical conditions such as skin, dental, and musculoskeletal issues, and owners may be eligible for assistance with veterinary care through nonprofit organizations or DOD medical facilities.</summary>

<summary>
The Comanche program was established in 1983 to replace the Army's light helicopter fleet with a low-cost, lightweight, advanced technology helicopter. The program experienced significant increases in program acquisition unit cost, with the estimated total program acquisition cost increasing from $61 billion for 5,023 aircraft in 1985 to over $44 billion for 1,292 aircraft in 1995. The program was restructured in 1994 to reduce funding from $4.2 billion to $2.2 billion for fiscal years 1996-2001, extending the development phase by 3 years. The Army proposed a restructure that would allow it to acquire six aircraft in addition to two prototypes by deferring developmental efforts to fiscal year 2002 and beyond. The program continues to face risks associated with concurrency, including production decisions being made before knowing whether the aircraft will perform as required. The Comanche will be the most computerized, software-intensive Army helicopter ever built, with over 2.7 million lines of code required to perform and integrate mission critical functions. The program is experiencing technical problems, including software development delays, maintainability issues, and weight growth. The General Accounting Office (GAO) recommends that the Secretary of Defense require the Army to complete operational testing to validate the Comanche's operational effectiveness and suitability before committing any funds to acquire long-lead production items or enter low-rate initial production.</summary>

<summary>The Food Stamp Program, administered by the US Department of Agriculture's Food and Nutrition Service (FNS), provides eligible low-income households with paper coupons or electronic benefits that can be redeemed for food in stores nationwide. To increase program access and reduce the reporting burden on working families, FNS has introduced several options and waivers to food stamp rules and regulations, including categorical eligibility, vehicle asset exemptions, and reporting alternatives.</summary>

The Food Stamp Program is a federal assistance program that provides food purchasing assistance to low-income individuals and families. The program is administered by the US Department of Agriculture's Food and Nutrition Service (FNS) and is funded by the federal government. The program provides eligible households with paper coupons or electronic benefits that can be redeemed for food in stores nationwide.

To be eligible for benefits, a household's gross income may not exceed 130 percent of the federal poverty level, and the value of its assets may not exceed $2,000. If the household owns a vehicle worth more than $4,650, the excess value is included in calculating the household's assets. Recipients of Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (TANF) cash assistance are automatically eligible for food stamps, a provision referred to as "categorical eligibility."

FNS has introduced several options and waivers to food stamp rules and regulations to increase program access and reduce the reporting burden on working families. These options and waivers include categorical eligibility, vehicle asset exemptions, and reporting alternatives. Categorical eligibility allows states to confer eligibility for food stamps on households receiving certain TANF-funded services or benefits. Vehicle asset exemptions allow states to exempt some or all vehicles from counting as assets in determining food stamp eligibility.

Reporting alternatives include quarterly and semiannual reporting, which decrease the frequency with which households with earnings are required to report changes in their circumstances. FNS also offers waivers to change reporting that reduce the reporting burden on households with earnings. The Transitional Benefit Alternative, introduced in November 2000, gives states the option to continue to provide families with their same food stamp benefit amount for 3 months after they leave welfare.

The Simplified Food Stamp Program option, which was intended to create conformity between TANF and the Food Stamp Program by merging the programs' rules into a single set of requirements for individuals receiving both types of assistance, has not been widely adopted by states. The main reason states gave for not choosing this option was that it was too complex and difficult to implement.

Overall, the Food Stamp Program is an important source of nutrition assistance for low-income individuals and families,

<summary>
The U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) was established in 1965 and is responsible for programs in four areas: housing assistance, community development, housing finance, and regulatory issues. HUD provides housing assistance through public housing and private-market housing assistance under section 8 of the U.S. Housing Act of 1937. The department also provides community development funds through grants to states and local governments. HUD's fiscal year 2000 budget request includes 19 new initiatives and programs, totaling $210 million in set-asides. The department is proposing a 9-percent increase in budget authority over fiscal year 1999, with a total budget of about $34 billion. However, the GAO has concerns about HUD's capacity to manage the increase, citing ongoing organizational reform and the need for dedicated resources to plan and implement new programs. The GAO also raised questions about HUD's Section 8 program request, including the basis for contract renewal costs and the use of unexpended balances. Additionally, the GAO expressed concerns about HUD's Contract Administration initiative, citing weaknesses in the department's contracting practices. The GAO recommended that HUD provide assurances to Congress that it has an adequate administrative structure and sufficient staffing in place to oversee the new contracting program.

<summary>The Department of Defense (DOD) is planning to replace the Landstuhl Regional Medical Center (LRMC) in Germany with a new medical center, which will serve as the only tertiary-level referral hospital for the EUCOM, Central Command, and Africa Command theaters of operation. However, the planning documentation for the new medical center contains inconsistencies, gaps, and calculation errors that raise concerns about the facility's ability to meet the needs of the expected beneficiary population in Europe. The Government Accountability Office (GAO) recommends that DOD provide sufficient and clear documentation on how medical planners applied DOD criteria to determine the facility's requirements and correct any calculation errors.</summary>

<summary>
The report examines the exercise of discretion by Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) officers in the alien apprehension and removal process, highlighting the need for comprehensive guidance and a mechanism to analyze officer decision making. ICE officers exercise discretion in various phases of the process, including initial encounter, apprehension, charging, detention, removal proceedings, and final removal, with more discretion available in the initial phases. However, ICE's guidance does not comprehensively address key aspects of the alien apprehension and removal process, such as dealing with humanitarian issues and aliens who are not investigation targets. The report recommends that ICE develop time frames for updating existing policies, develop a mechanism to ensure officers are consistently provided with updates on legal developments, and evaluate the costs and alternatives of developing a reporting mechanism to analyze trends in the use of discretion.

</summary>

<summary>

Ground ambulance services are provided by various organizations with different structures, staffing, and revenue sources. Medicare payments for ambulance services consist of a service-level payment and a mileage payment. Providers may be affiliated with institutions or be independent, and they may specialize in nonemergency or emergency transports. Some providers offer basic life support (BLS) services, while others offer advanced life support (ALS) services, which require specialized medical technicians. Revenue sources for providers include community tax support, charitable donations, and payments from Medicare, Medicaid, and private insurance companies. Medicare pays ambulance providers through a national fee schedule, with two components: a service-level payment and a mileage payment. The mileage payment is determined by the number of miles traveled and the mileage base rate, with a 50% increase for rural and super-rural transports since 2002. A 2010 survey of 154 ambulance providers found that costs per transport ranged from $224 to $2,204, with a median cost of $429. The survey also found that providers with lower transport volumes had higher costs per transport, and that personnel costs accounted for the largest percentage of total costs. The survey results showed that Medicare margins were positive 2% in 2010, but would have been negative 1% without add-on payments.

</summary>

<summary>

The Department of Defense (DOD) is responsible for managing SRC I ammunition, which is a high-risk conventional ammunition. The Army has a prominent role in managing SRC I ammunition, as it procures a majority of the department's ammunition and provides wholesale storage for other military services. The military services have automated information systems to manage accountability and visibility of SRC I ammunition, but there are limitations and inconsistencies in these systems. The DOD is in the final stages of evaluating various automated information systems to be designated as the DOD-wide authoritative source of data for conventional ammunition. The military services have not consistently ensured timely, complete, and accurate information to maintain full visibility of SRC I ammunition in the continental United States. The GAO made six recommendations to enhance the department's policy and procedures and improve the accountability and visibility of SRC I ammunition. The DOD concurred with all six recommendations and has taken steps to address the issues identified in the report. The GAO's review found that the military services have made progress in improving their management of SRC I ammunition, but there are still areas for improvement.

</summary>

<summary>
The Social Security Administration (SSA) has a restrictive disclosure policy for law enforcement requests, which goes beyond the requirements of the Privacy Act. The policy requires SSA officials to consider several factors before releasing individuals' personal information, including the nature of the alleged criminal activity and the agency making the request. SSA's policy is more restrictive than most federal agencies, with the IRS and Census Bureau being exceptions, as their disclosure policies are specifically provided in statute. Despite the policy's restrictions, SSA officials have expressed concerns about expanding the policy, citing the need to protect individuals' privacy and maintain the agency's pledge of confidentiality. The Government Accountability Office (GAO) recommends that the SSA Commissioner take steps to eliminate confusion about the agency's disclosure policy and provide law enforcement with information on SSA's disclosure policy and procedures.</summary>

<summary>
The Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA) of 1976 aims to minimize threats to human health and the environment by regulating the management of hazardous waste. However, the law's requirements have been criticized for creating disincentives for industry to clean up contaminated sites, particularly for remediation waste. The three main requirements that contribute to these disincentives are land disposal restrictions, minimum technological requirements, and requirements for permits. These requirements can increase costs and time for cleanups, leading parties to choose less aggressive remedies or avoid cleanups altogether. The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has proposed alternative policies to mitigate the impact of these requirements, but stakeholders disagree on the extent to which waste should be exempt from RCRA's requirements. The EPA has concluded that comprehensive reform of remediation waste management can best be achieved through legislative action, and has recommended that the Administrator take steps to ensure that regulators have a consistent understanding of how to apply EPA's existing policy and regulatory alternatives.</summary>

<summary>The Medicare Integrity Program (MIP) was established in 1997 to support program integrity activities, and since then, the program has undergone significant changes, including increases in funding and shifts in focus. Despite these changes, the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) has not effectively allocated MIP funds, with some activities receiving more funding than others based on historical allocations rather than effectiveness. To improve the allocation of MIP funds, CMS should develop a method that takes into account the effectiveness of program integrity activities, contractors' workloads, and risk, and consider both quantitative and qualitative measures of effectiveness.</summary>

<summary>
The Transportation Security Administration (TSA) has been working to enhance the training of screeners and supervisors to improve the effectiveness of passenger and checked baggage screening operations. Despite efforts to improve training, weaknesses and vulnerabilities continue to exist in the passenger and checked baggage screening systems. The TSA has implemented a basic screener training program and required remedial training, but has not fully developed or deployed a recurrent training program for screeners or supervisors. The agency has collected limited data to measure screener performance, and its covert testing results have identified weaknesses in screeners' ability to detect threat objects. The TSA has also implemented the Threat Image Projection (TIP) system to test passenger screeners' detection capabilities, but it is not yet available for checked baggage screening. The agency has established performance measures and indexes for the passenger and checked baggage screening systems, but has not established targets for the various components of the screening indexes. The TSA has made significant accomplishments in meeting congressional mandates related to establishing screening operations, but has turned its attention to assessing and enhancing the effectiveness of its passenger and checked baggage screening systems. To address these challenges, the TSA plans to develop a plan to prioritize and schedule the deployment of high-speed Internet/intranet connectivity to all airport training facilities and to develop internal controls to monitor and document the completion of required training. The Government Accountability Office (GAO) recommends that the Secretary of the Department of Homeland Security direct the TSA to take these actions to ensure that all screeners have timely and complete access to screener training and that TSA management has reasonable assurance that all screeners are receiving required training.

<summary>
The Internal Revenue Service (IRS) has a toll-free customer service network with 10,000 representatives at 25 call sites across the country. However, the IRS faces challenges in managing its human capital, including recruiting, training, and retaining customer service representatives, due to the broad range of complex topics they must address and inadequate resources. The IRS also struggles with inaccurate demand forecasting and a complicated staff scheduling process, leading to inefficient use of staff and resources. To address these challenges, the IRS is implementing an automated system to forecast demand and schedule staff, and is working to establish a long-term, desired service-level goal based on taxpayers' needs. The Government Accountability Office (GAO) recommends that the IRS establish a system for assessing competency gaps and refresher training needs, monitor attrition, and evaluate human capital management practices to optimize the efficiency and effectiveness of its toll-free operations.</summary>

<summary>

Ginnie Mae is a government agency that provides guarantees for mortgage-backed securities (MBS) backed by government-insured or guaranteed loans. The agency's mission is to expand affordable housing in America by linking capital markets to the nation's housing markets. Ginnie Mae does not buy or sell loans or issue MBS, but rather provides guarantees backed by the full faith and credit of the U.S. government. The agency has several different products, including Ginnie Mae I and Ginnie Mae II, which allow for more heterogeneous loans. Ginnie Mae's securities finance the great majority of FHA and VA loans, and the agency has consistently captured 90% or more of the market for these loans. However, Ginnie Mae's share of the total MBS market has declined significantly since 1985, due in part to the growth of the conventional MBS market. The agency faces challenges in responding to changes in the marketplace and meeting the needs of its stakeholders, including improving its data systems and disclosures. Ginnie Mae has taken steps to address these challenges, including expanding its product offerings and improving its disclosures. The agency's commitment authority is limited, and it must suspend issuance of new MBS if it exhausts its authority. Ginnie Mae's staff is small, and the agency relies heavily on contractors to carry out its operations, which raises concerns about its ability to ensure effective contract management and oversight.

</summary>

<summary>
The Department of Defense (DOD) has made significant progress in correcting $615 million of illegal and otherwise improper closed account adjustments identified in a prior report. DOD has reversed $592 million of the adjustments, but additional reviews are needed to determine the correct accounting for these adjustments. The reversal of the adjustments has brought to light additional accounting problems that require detailed reviews to correct. DOD officials estimate that it will take over 21,000 hours to correct the accounting for 30 contracts that were affected by the reversals. The DOD has also implemented new controls to prevent illegal closed account adjustments, resulting in an 80% reduction in such adjustments during the first 6 months of fiscal year 2002. However, the DOD's financial management problems are long-term and complex, and the agency still needs to address its overall disbursement problems.

<summary>
The Internet has grown significantly in importance to American businesses and consumers, serving as a host for hundreds of billions of dollars of commerce each year. The Internet relies on the domain name system to ensure the uniqueness of each e-mail and Web site address. The U.S. government supported the implementation of the domain name system for nearly a decade, largely through a Department of Defense contract. In 1997, the Department of Commerce began a process for transitioning the technical responsibility for the domain name system to the private sector. The Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (ICANN) was established to manage the domain name system, and it entered into a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) with the Department of Commerce to guide the transition. ICANN made significant progress in carrying out MOU tasks related to increasing competition, but progress has been slower on activities designed to address stability and security. ICANN's president concluded that the corporation faced serious problems in accomplishing the transition and needed fundamental reform. ICANN's Board established an internal committee to recommend options for reform, and the Department of Commerce welcomed the call for reform. The Department of Commerce is responsible for general oversight of work done under the MOU and will assess the necessity for adjustments or legislative or executive action depending on the results of the reform process. The Department of Commerce is expected to issue a status report detailing its assessment of the progress made on transition tasks and the estimated timeframe for completing the transition.

<summary>
The Office of the Special Trustee for American Indians (OST) was established in 1994 to oversee the trust management reform for the Department of the Interior. Since its inception, OST has made significant progress in implementing trust reforms, including the development of a comprehensive trust management plan, the creation of a trust portal, and the implementation of a trust funds accounting system. However, despite the progress made, OST has not provided a timetable for completing the remaining trust reforms, and the Special Trustee has not developed a plan for future trust fund operations once reforms are completed. The Special Trustee believes that OST's staff will need to continue to perform their functions after trust reforms are completed, but a reexamination of OST's workforce needs might identify opportunities for realigning or further reducing expenditures and staffing levels. The Government Accountability Office (GAO) recommends that the Secretary of the Interior direct the Special Trustee to provide a timetable for completing the trust fund management reforms and a plan for future trust fund operations, as well as to develop a workforce plan that reexamines and proposes staffing levels and funding needs.</summary>

<summary>
In 1998, the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) and the Department of Defense (DOD) began a joint effort to develop a comprehensive, life-long medical record for each service member. The Government Computer-Based Patient Record (GCPR) project was initiated, but it faced difficulties due to a lack of a lead entity, clear mission, and detailed planning. The project was later revised and renamed the Federal Health Information Exchange (FHIE) program, which enabled the one-way transfer of data from DOD's health information system to VA's system. The departments continued to work on the project, and by 2004, they had made progress toward being able to electronically share patient health data. The departments are now working on a longer-term goal to achieve a virtual medical record based on the two-way exchange of computable data between their health information systems. However, they face challenges in developing a project management plan and overcoming technical limitations in their data repositories.</summary>

<summary>

The Internal Revenue Manual (IRM) describes the desired outcome of an income tax audit as determining the correct taxable income and tax liability of the person or entity under audit. The IRS uses nine audit standards to define audit quality, which address issues such as scope, techniques, technical conclusions, reports, and time management. Audit workpapers provide documentation on the scope of the audit and the diligence with which it was completed. The primary tool used by the IRS to control quality under the nine standards is the review of ongoing audit work by first-line supervisors, called group managers. The Examination Quality Measurement System (EQMS) is used to collect information about the audit process, changes to the process, level of audit quality, and success of any efforts to improve the process and quality. A review of IRS audit workpapers found that auditors did not always meet the requirements laid out under the workpaper standard. The workpaper standard requires that workpapers provide the principal support for the auditor's report and document the procedures applied, tests performed, information obtained, and conclusions reached. The review found that tax adjustments shown in the workpapers, summaries, and reports did not always agree, and required documents or summaries were not always in the workpaper bundle. The IRS has historically found problems with the quality of its workpapers, with EQMS evaluations indicating that auditors met all of the key elements of the workpaper standard in no more than 72 percent of the audits. The IRS is currently drafting changes to the IRM relating to workpapers, which will require documentation of managerial involvement in the audit process.</summary>

<summary>
The Anti-Terrorism Assistance (ATA) program was authorized by Congress in 1983 through the Foreign Assistance Act, with the purpose of enhancing antiterrorism skills of friendly countries, strengthening bilateral ties, and increasing respect for human rights. The program offers training courses and grants of counterterrorism equipment to partner nations. In fiscal year 2002, appropriations for ATA increased to $158 million, and by fiscal year 2007, it had increased to almost $171 million. The top 10 recipients of ATA allocations received between $11 million and $78 million, while the other 89 partner nations received between $9,000 and $10.7 million. The Coordinator for Counterterrorism (S/CT) and the Assistant Secretary for Diplomatic Security (DS/T/ATA) have specific roles and responsibilities regarding ATA, but they did not systematically use country-specific needs assessments and program reviews to plan assistance. The assessments and reviews had weaknesses and inconsistencies, and DS/T/ATA officials in the field made program and resource decisions based on their knowledge and experience rather than the assessments. State has made progress in establishing goals and measures related to the program's mandated objectives, but it lacks clear measures and processes for assessing sustainability. The Government Performance and Results Act of 1993 requires agencies to identify goals and report on the degree to which goals are met, but State has not complied with this mandate since 1996. State agreed with the Government Accountability Office's (GAO) recommendations to improve the ATA program guidance, needs assessment and program review process, and assessments of ATA program outcomes.</summary>

<summary>
The U.S. Bankruptcy Code provides two approaches for reorganizing or terminating large financial companies: judicial bankruptcy process and special legal and regulatory resolution regimes. The judicial bankruptcy process involves filing a petition under Chapter 7 or Chapter 11, which can be voluntary or involuntary, and allows debtors to restructure or liquidate their assets. The special resolution regimes, such as the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation's (FDIC) Orderly Liquidation Authority (OLA), provide an alternative to bankruptcy and allow for the resolution of systemically important financial institutions. Despite efforts to improve cross-border coordination, the resolution of large financial companies remains a complex and challenging process, with ongoing litigation and disputes in cases such as Lehman Brothers Holdings, Inc., MF Global Holdings, Ltd., and Washington Mutual, Inc.</summary>

<summary>The electricity industry is composed of four distinct functions: generation, transmission, distribution, and system operations, and its modernization is an ongoing process with the goal of creating a more reliable and efficient smart grid that facilitates alternative forms of generation and gives consumers real-time information about fluctuating energy costs. However, the industry faces significant cybersecurity risks due to its increasing reliance on IT systems and networks, and key entities such as NERC, FERC, NIST, and DHS have roles to play in providing guidance and support for protecting the sector against cyber threats.</summary>

<summary>
The federal government faces significant skills gaps in various occupations, including cybersecurity, acquisitions, and nursing, which hinder its ability to serve the public effectively and achieve results. The government's outdated pay system, classification system, and performance management system contribute to these gaps, and the impending wave of employee retirements threatens to exacerbate the problem. To address these issues, the government should update its compensation system to be more market-based and performance-oriented, and agencies should make effective use of tools and flexibilities provided by Congress to build and maintain a high-performing workforce. The Government Accountability Office (GAO) has made several recommendations to improve human capital management, including strengthening hiring efforts, modernizing the classification system, and promoting effective performance management.</summary>

<summary>
The Department of Defense (DOD) received about $52.4 billion in supplemental appropriations for Global War on Terrorism (GWOT) military personnel and operation and maintenance expenses in fiscal year 2004, and about $62.1 billion in fiscal year 2005. However, DOD and the military services have lost visibility over these funds, including knowing how much was used to support GWOT in fiscal years 2004 and 2005. The DOD's accounting systems do not separately identify the portion of the department's annual appropriations that were described as having been requested to support GWOT, making it difficult to track how these funds are being used. The Government Accountability Office (GAO) recommends that the Secretary of Defense adjust future supplemental appropriations requests to reflect the additional funds DOD received in its annual appropriations to support GWOT and provide an explanation of these adjustments to the Congress. The GAO also recommends that DOD consider the additional GWOT funds provided through DOD's annual appropriations in addressing any future GWOT funding needs and document its decisions.</summary>

<summary>The Troubled Asset Relief Program (TARP) was extended by the Department of the Treasury to address ongoing weaknesses in the economy, including housing market indicators and financial conditions for small businesses. The extension of TARP provided flexibility to modify the Making Home Affordable Program (MHA) to respond to the changing dynamics of the foreclosure crisis and to support small business lending. Treasury officials considered a number of qualitative and quantitative factors for key decisions associated with the TARP extension, including ongoing weaknesses in key areas of the economy and the need to retain resources to respond to threats to financial stability.</summary>

<summary>The US government, through the FDA and USDA, has taken steps to enhance food security at processing facilities, including issuing voluntary guidelines and conducting risk assessments, but lacks the authority to mandate security measures and collect information on industry's voluntary implementation of security measures. The agencies are recommending that the Secretary of Health and Human Services and the Secretary of Agriculture study their agencies' existing statutes and identify additional authorities needed to regulate security at food-processing facilities.</summary>

<summary>
The MAS program, also known as the Federal Supply Schedule, is the largest interagency contracting vehicle in the federal government, managed by the General Services Administration (GSA). The program allows federal agencies to leverage their buying power and avoid administrative costs. However, the government lacks reliable and comprehensive data to effectively manage and oversee these contracts. The Federal Procurement Data System-Next Generation (FPDS-NG) is insufficient and unreliable for identifying MACs and enterprisewide contracts. The GAO made recommendations to improve data, strengthen policy, and better coordinate agencies' awards of MACs and enterprisewide contracts. The GAO also identified challenges in managing the MAS program, including a lack of transactional data and limited use of selected pricing tools. The GAO recommended that GSA take steps to collect transactional data and improve the use of pricing tools to determine whether the program achieves its goal of obtaining the best prices for customers and taxpayers. The government's inability to effectively manage and oversee these contracts hampers its ability to minimize duplication and take advantage of the government's buying power through more efficient and strategic contracting.

<summary>
The federal government has invested billions of dollars in IT projects, but some have become costly and unproductive mistakes. The Office of Personnel Management's Retirement Systems Modernization program, the National Polar-orbiting Operational Environmental Satellite System, the Department of Veterans Affairs' Scheduling Replacement Project, and the Department of Health and Human Services' Healthcare.gov website are examples of failed IT projects. To address these issues, the government created 18F and USDS, two programs aimed at improving public-facing federal digital services. 18F was established in 2014 by GSA to transform the way the federal government builds and buys digital services, while USDS was launched in 2014 to transform the most important digital services for citizens. Both programs have provided various development and consulting services to agencies, with 18F helping 18 agencies with 32 projects and USDS assisting 11 agencies with 13 projects. The programs have also developed products and services, such as cloud.gov and a shared authentication platform, to support digital services. However, both programs have faced challenges, including a lack of clear goals and performance measures, and have not fully implemented important program management practices. The Government Accountability Office (GAO) has recommended that GSA and OMB take steps to improve the programs' performance, including establishing outcome-oriented goals and measuring performance. The GAO has also recommended that OMB update USDS policy to clearly define the responsibilities and authorities governing the relationships between CIOs and digital services teams.</summary>

<summary>

The baby boom generation, born between 1946 and 1964, is aging and will soon begin moving from traditional working ages to retirement. This will lead to significant changes in the ratio of working-age individuals to those 65 or older, known as the aged dependency ratio. The ratio is expected to rise from 21% in 2000 to 35% by 2030, meaning there will be fewer than three working-age individuals for every person 65 or older. The labor force growth of younger workers has slowed, and the number of older workers will grow substantially over the next two decades. Older workers are employed in a diverse range of occupations and are a growing proportion of white-collar workers. Between 2000 and 2008, the number and percentage of workers over age 55 will increase in all major occupational categories, with the largest change expected in white-collar occupations. Employers are experimenting with flexible employment arrangements, such as part-time work and phased retirement programs, to retain older workers, but these programs are not yet widespread. The ERISA Advisory Council has recommended that the Secretary of Labor convene an interagency task force to develop legislative and regulatory proposals to address the issues raised by the aging of the labor force.</summary>

<summary>
The Visa Waiver Program (VWP) was created in 1986 to facilitate legitimate travel to the United States for business or tourism purposes. The program has expanded to 36 countries and requires participating countries to meet certain security and information-sharing requirements. The Electronic System for Travel Authorization (ESTA) was implemented in 2008 to enhance program security and requires VWP travelers to apply for approval prior to travel. Despite some challenges, ESTA has reduced the burden on VWP travelers and improved security, but DHS has not fully analyzed the risks of carrier and passenger noncompliance with the requirement. Only half of the VWP countries have entered into all required information-sharing agreements, and DHS has not completed half of the mandated biennial reports in a timely manner. To address these issues, the GAO recommends that the Secretary of Homeland Security establish time frames for regular review of ESTA compliance and take steps to address delays in the biennial country review process.</summary>

<summary>The US child welfare system has been struggling to keep pace with the growing number of foster care cases, with the foster care population increasing from 276,000 in 1984 to 494,000 in 1995. To address this issue, states have implemented various initiatives, such as concurrent planning, expedited permanency hearings, and specialized programs to reunite families and expedite the adoption process, but the effectiveness of these initiatives is often hindered by the lack of systematic evaluations and data.</summary>

<summary>
The Digital Accountability and Transparency Act (DATA Act) was signed into law on May 9, 2014, requiring federal agencies to disclose expenditures and link agency spending information to federal program activities. The act requires government-wide reporting on a greater variety of federal funds, including budget and financial information, and tracking of these funds at multiple points in the federal spending lifecycle. To improve data quality, the act requires agency-reported award and financial information to comply with new data standards established by the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) and the Department of the Treasury. OMB and Treasury have taken steps to help agencies meet their reporting requirements, including establishing standardized data element definitions and issuing guidance on reporting requirements. However, agencies have identified several challenges that will affect the quality of data posted on USASpending.gov, including how to report intragovernmental transactions and missing or incorrect ZIP+4 information. The Government Accountability Office (GAO) has identified several risks to data quality, including material weaknesses and significant deficiencies in internal controls over financial reporting and financial management systems. The GAO has made several recommendations to OMB and Treasury to improve the completeness and accuracy of data submissions to USASpending.gov, including clarifying guidance on agency responsibilities for reporting awards funded by non-annual appropriations and developing a government-wide oversight process to regularly assess the consistency of information reported by federal agencies. OMB and Treasury have taken some steps to address these recommendations, but more work remains to be done to ensure effective implementation of the DATA Act.</summary>

<summary>
The Office of Special Counsel (OSC) contracted with MPRI for an organizational assessment without following proper contracting procedures. The agreement between OSC and ARC, an office within the Treasury's Bureau of the Public Debt, was a mechanism for interagency contracting. OSC officials performed duties normally done by contracting officer's representatives without authorization or training, and they also performed other duties that should have been reserved for the contracting officer. The sole-source justification for the contract was inadequate, and the price reasonableness assessment was not properly documented. The OSC officials who hired an intermittent consultant, Alan J. Hicks, used their discretion to approve his appointment and set his compensation rate, which was consistent with OPM regulations. However, OSC employees who believe a prohibited personnel practice has occurred may face difficulties in addressing their allegations, particularly when the Special Counsel or Deputy Special Counsel is involved. To address these difficulties, Congress should consider affording OSC employees alternative means of addressing prohibited personnel practice allegations, such as an external investigation or an expansion of the personnel actions that could be appealed directly to the MSPB. The Director of ARC's Division of Procurement and the Special Counsel should take steps to ensure that contracting procedures are followed and that OSC employees have alternative avenues of redress.</summary>

<summary>
The Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) has a mission to promote the health, welfare, and dignity of all veterans by ensuring they receive medical care, benefits, and social support. The VA has three major components: the Veterans Benefits Administration (VBA), the Veterans Health Administration (VHA), and the National Cemetery Administration (NCA). The VA relies on approximately 340,000 employees to provide services and benefits, and operates an IT infrastructure that supports its mission. The VA operates approximately 240 information systems, manages 314,000 desktop computers and 30,000 laptops, and administers nearly 460,000 network user accounts. The VA has identified several legacy systems that are in need of modernization or replacement, including the 53-year-old Personnel and Accounting Integrated Data (PAID) system and the 51-year-old Benefits Delivery Network (BDN) system. The VA has a 6-year strategic plan that emphasizes increasing veterans' access to benefits and services, eliminating the disability claims backlog, and ending veteran homelessness. The VA has reported spending about $3.9 billion to improve and maintain its IT resources in fiscal year 2015, and has requested appropriations of about $4.3 billion for IT in fiscal year 2017. The VA's CIO has initiated an effort to transform the focus and functions of the Office of Information and Technology (OI&T), and has established five new functions within OI&T. The VA faces challenges in key areas, including the development of new systems, modernization of existing systems, and increasing interoperability with the Department of Defense (DOD). The Government Accountability Office (GAO) has recommended that the VA develop a plan with a time frame and a reliable cost estimate for completing its Veterans Benefits Management System (VBMS), and that the VA modernize its claims processing system to improve timeliness and efficiency.</summary>

<summary>
The Medicare program, managed by the Health Care Financing Administration (HCFA), faces significant challenges due to its vast size and complexity. HCFA is struggling to implement recent reforms, including the Balanced Budget Act of 1997 (BBA), which introduced new health plan options and payment reforms, while also dealing with the loss of experienced staff and the need for specialized expertise. The agency's reorganization efforts are also being hindered by the timing of the changes, which coincide with tight deadlines and pressures. As a result, HCFA may not be able to adequately justify the resources it seeks to carry out its other Medicare program objectives, highlighting the need for effective implementation of new legislation to reduce fraud and abuse.</summary>

<summary>

The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) is primarily supported by the Trust Fund, which receives revenues from excise taxes paid by users of the National Airspace System (NAS). The Trust Fund was established by the Airport and Airway Revenue Act of 1970 to help fund the development of a nationwide airport and airway system. The administration's reauthorization proposal would change FAA's financing system from one based mainly on excise taxes to one based more on cost-based charges. The proposed system would fund the Air Traffic Organization (ATO) primarily through user charges on commercial aircraft and fuel taxes on general aviation aircraft. The proposal would also create an advisory board and give FAA limited borrowing authority. FAA's new cost allocation study divides NAS users into two groups: high-performance aircraft and piston aircraft. However, the study has raised concerns about its methodology, and more time may be needed to analyze the differences among aircraft types that lead to differences in the costs they impose on the NAS. The proposed funding structure may not yield the revenue that FAA expects to collect from fuel taxes due to possible reductions in fuel purchases. The administration's proposal to align FAA's budget accounts with FAA's lines of business has advantages and disadvantages, and linking the General Fund contribution to FAA's budget would explicitly recognize that users of the system are not the only beneficiaries of it. The administration's proposal deserves serious and thoughtful consideration, but adopting it is not necessary to provide more money to FAA if Congress thinks that additional spending on aviation is needed.

</summary>

<summary>The General Services Administration (GSA) is planning the FTS Networx acquisition program to replace the existing FTS2001, Federal Wireless Telecommunications Service, and FTS Satellite Service contracts, with the goal of providing federal agencies with competitively priced telecommunications services and solutions to meet their mission needs. However, GSA faces significant challenges in finalizing its program strategy, including ensuring adequate inventory information, establishing measures of success, and structuring and scheduling the contracts to ensure a smooth transition from current contracts to Networx.</summary>

<summary>The Federal Student Aid (FSA) program, established as a Performance-Based Organization (PBO) in 1998, has made progress in improving customer and employee satisfaction, but faces challenges in implementing its performance plan, particularly in areas such as systems integration and program integrity. To address these challenges, the FSA needs to improve its reporting of progress, clarify its unit cost calculation, and develop a comprehensive human capital strategy to ensure its workforce is adequately prepared to meet future challenges.</summary>

<summary>
The National Institutes of Health (NIH) made over 21,500 grant awards using Recovery Act funds by the end of fiscal year 2010. These grants supported various research projects, and the NIH reported that the number of full-time equivalents (FTEs) supported by Recovery Act funds increased from December 2009 to June 2011, with a total of approximately 54,000 FTEs expected to be supported throughout the Recovery Act. A review of data from five grantee institutions found that the number of FTEs supported by Recovery Act funds increased from almost 1,000 in December 2009 to almost 2,000 in June 2011. Principal investigators reported that Recovery Act funding supported new positions, avoided reductions in employee numbers, and enabled the purchase of research supplies and equipment. The NIH is participating in the Star Metrics program to track the employment, scientific, and economic impacts of its funded research projects, including Recovery Act grants.</summary>

<summary>

Transit-oriented development (TOD) is a compact, mixed-use, and walkable neighborhood located near transit, typically within a half-mile of a transit station. Research suggests that TOD can increase access to employment, education, and cultural opportunities by promoting transportation options and reducing road congestion. The Federal Transit Administration (FTA) does not have a discrete program for TOD, but it has been expanding its role in TOD by funding research, coordinating with other agencies, and implementing a planning pilot program. Local transit agencies, state and local departments of transportation, and metropolitan planning organizations play important roles in planning and implementing TOD. Private developers, lenders, and business improvement districts also contribute to TOD. The FTA evaluates proposed projects for New Starts funding based on six criteria, including mobility improvements, environmental benefits, and land use. Factors that support TOD include market demand for real estate, available land for development, resident support for transit, and efficient access to jobs and centers of activity. Challenges to TOD include higher construction costs, lenders' reluctance to finance TOD, lengthy or discretionary local development approval processes, and unsupportive local populations. Local governments can use policies such as zoning regulations, station area planning, and targeted infrastructure investments to encourage TOD. The FTA's assessment of proposed projects is consistent with the factors that local stakeholders told us affect project results, but there are inherent limitations in the extent to which some factors can be fully evaluated.

</summary>

<summary>
The Social Security Administration (SSA) has been sending the Personal Earnings and Benefit Estimate Statement (PEBES) to workers since 1988, which allows them to review their earnings records and obtain benefit estimates. However, the SSA has found that fewer than 2 percent of workers request these statements each year. The SSA plans to mail statements automatically to over 70 million workers by fiscal year 2000, with the goal of better informing the public about benefits available under SSA's programs, assisting workers in planning for their financial future, and ensuring that Social Security earnings records are complete and accurate. The PEBES benefit estimates are based on certain assumptions about an individual's future employment and earnings, but do not take into consideration special circumstances that could affect a worker's actual retirement benefit. The SSA has conducted several surveys and focus groups to assess the public's reaction to receiving an unsolicited PEBES, and has made revisions to the statement in response to feedback. However, the current statement still provides too much information and is too complex, and the SSA has not collected detailed information from its front-line workers on the public's response to the PEBES. The GAO recommends that the SSA revise the current statement to improve its layout and design, simplify explanations, and evaluate alternative formats for communicating the information presented in the PEBES.</summary>

<summary>The Social Security Administration (SSA) administers two programs, Disability Insurance (DI) and Supplemental Security Income (SSI), which provide benefits for individuals with disabilities. Concurrent beneficiaries, who receive benefits from both programs, make up about 14% of the SSA's disability population and are more likely to have mental impairments and be female. The SSA faces challenges in serving concurrent beneficiaries, including a lack of integrated guidance and procedures, which can lead to overpayments and underpayments of benefits. To address these challenges, the SSA has implemented initiatives, such as training for field office employees and the development of new software, but further steps are needed to ensure effective administration of the disability program and serve concurrent beneficiaries.</summary>

<summary>The federal government has not adequately tracked and reported on the use of $88 billion in hurricane relief and recovery funds provided to 23 federal agencies in the four emergency supplemental appropriations acts, making it difficult for decision makers to determine how much federal funding has been spent and by whom. To improve the information on the status of hurricane relief and recovery funds, the Government Accountability Office recommends that the Secretary of Homeland Security direct the Director of FEMA to take certain actions and that the Director, Office of Management and Budget, establish a framework for governmentwide reporting on the status of hurricane-related funding.</summary>

<summary>
The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has authority to authorize all Unmanned Aircraft Systems (UAS) operations in the national airspace, but currently only allows access on a case-by-case basis. The FAA provides access through three means: Certificates of Waiver or Authorization (COA), Special Airworthiness Certificates in the Experimental Category, and Section 333 exemptions. The FAA has been planning for further integration and has issued the UAS Comprehensive Plan and the UAS Integration Roadmap, which outline a three-phase approach: Accommodation, Integration, and Evolution. The FAA has also issued a proposed rule for small UAS operations, which would allow greater access to the national airspace, but has faced challenges in processing comments and developing a detailed implementation plan. The FAA is working to make test sites more accessible and has begun a public education campaign to increase awareness and inform prospective users on flying safely and responsibly.</summary>

<summary>

The Commander's Emergency Response Program (CERP) in Afghanistan has unique development, security, and infrastructure issues compared to Iraq, with a focus on development and construction. The program has evolved over time, with projects becoming more complex and costly, from small-scale projects like wells to large-scale projects like road construction. In fiscal year 2008, 90% of CERP projects in Afghanistan cost $200,000 or less. Management and execution of the CERP program is the responsibility of officials at CJTF-101 headquarters, brigades, and Provincial Reconstruction Teams (PRTs). However, DOD faces significant challenges in providing adequate management and oversight of CERP due to an insufficient number of trained personnel. The lack of personnel has led to problems with project oversight, site visits, and contractor performance. Additionally, personnel lack training on their duties and responsibilities, and training provided is often insufficient. DOD and USAID have established coordination mechanisms to facilitate coordination, but lack a common database to track development projects in Afghanistan. A centralized project-development database is being developed by USAID, but its development and implementation are still in the preliminary stages. The GAO recommends that the Secretary of Defense direct the commander of U.S. Central Command to evaluate workforce requirements and ensure adequate staff to administer the CERP program, and collaborate with USAID to create a centralized project-development database.

</summary>

<summary>The report examines the federal government's support for solar energy technology through 65 initiatives across six agencies, including the Department of Defense, Department of Energy, National Aeronautics and Space Administration, National Science Foundation, Environmental Protection Agency, and the United States Department of Agriculture. These initiatives supported a range of solar energy technologies, including photovoltaics, concentrated solar power, and solar hot water, and involved various technology advancement activities, such as basic research, applied research, demonstration, and commercialization. The report found that while there was some overlap and fragmentation among the initiatives, there was no clear evidence of duplication of efforts, and agency officials reported engaging in various coordination activities to avoid duplication and leverage resources. The report concludes that the federal government's support for solar energy technology is a complex and multifaceted effort that requires continued coordination and collaboration among agencies to achieve its goals.</summary>

<summary>

The Department of Defense (DOD) may be unable to prevent an attack using chemical or biological weapons, so it has determined that servicemembers must be protected to survive and conduct effective military operations. DOD supplies servicemembers with a protective ensemble consisting of a suit, mask with breathing filter, rubber boots, butyl gloves, and hoods as required. However, the existing equipment can cause unacceptable heat stress, limit freedom of movement, and is not fully interoperable across the services. To address these issues, DOD developed new, lightweight individual protective equipment such as the Joint Service Lightweight Integrated Suit Technology (JSLIST) trousers and coat. DOD plans to spend about $5.7 billion on planning for chemical and biological defense, acquisition of defense equipment, facilities construction, and research and development from 2002 to 2007. The DOD's current inventory management system is unreliable, and the Department's risk assessment process is flawed, leading to inaccurate risk assessments. The services collectively had no more than 4,348,999 suits of all types on hand as of September 30, 2000, but DOD reported a shortage of about 1.7 million protective suits. DOD's plan to buy fewer new suits is influenced by expiration of the suits and budgetary considerations, which will increase the short-term risk of wartime shortages. The Department of Defense's risk assessment process is based on individual equipment items and not ensembles, which obscures service-specific shortages. To improve the Department's ability to accurately assess the level of risk and readiness, the GAO recommends that DOD implement a fully integrated inventory management system and conduct risk assessments on the basis of ensembles required in wartime.

</summary>

<summary>
Program evaluations are systematic studies that use research methods to address specific questions about program performance. The Government Performance and Results Modernization Act (GPRAMA) of 2010 aimed to improve the use of performance information in decision making, but a 2017 survey of federal managers found that most managers lacked recent evaluations of their programs. The survey found that 40% of federal managers reported having access to recent evaluations, but many managers were unaware of evaluations conducted by others within or outside their agency. Evaluations were found to contribute to understanding program performance, assessing program effectiveness, and making changes to improve program management or performance. However, a lack of resources to implement evaluation findings was cited as a major barrier to evaluation use. The survey also found that agency leadership support for evaluation, staff involvement, and evaluation relevance to decision makers facilitated evaluation use. To address the lack of evaluation capacity, the Government Accountability Office (GAO) recommends that the Director of the Office of Management and Budget direct each of the 24 Chief Financial Officer Act agencies to prepare an annual agency-wide evaluation plan. This plan should describe the key questions for each significant evaluation study and the stakeholders that were consulted in preparing the plan.</summary>

<summary>
The Rehabilitation Act defines a disability as a physical or mental impairment that substantially limits one or more major life activities. To promote the employment of individuals with disabilities in the federal workforce, federal statutes and regulations provide special hiring authorities, such as Schedule A excepted service hiring authority. Executive Order 13548 requires federal agencies to develop plans for hiring and retaining employees with disabilities and to designate a senior-level official to be accountable for meeting the goals of the order. However, nearly 2 years after the executive order was signed, the federal government is not on track to achieve the executive order's goals, with many agency plans not meeting the criteria identified by OPM. To address these issues, the Director of OPM is recommended to incorporate information about plan deficiencies into its regular reporting, expedite the development of mandatory training programs, and assess the accuracy of SF-256 data.

<summary>
The Bureau of Land Management (BLM) is developing the Automated Land and Mineral Records System (ALMRS) to manage public lands and resources. The project, known as ALMRS/Modernization, aims to automate land and mineral records and case processing activities, provide information to support land and resource management activities, and increase public access to BLM records through the Internet. Despite making progress, the project faces challenges, including a tight development schedule, limited time to deal with unexpected problems, and the need for thorough stress testing of the entire system before deployment. The BLM has agreed to stress test the entire ALMRS/Modernization system to ensure it can process workloads expected during peak operating periods.

</summary>

<summary>
